Award.AwardTitle: A New Detector for Measuring Polarized Light: Modeling, Characterization, and Testing for Significantly Improved Imaging Capabilities.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract Title: A New Detector for Measuring Polarized Light: Modeling, Characterization, and
Testing for Significantly Improved Imaging Capabilities.

Nontechnical Abstract: Current polarized light photodetectors suffer from low spatial and/or temporal resolution,
or they experience systematic error. This is due to multiple detectors needed to fully characterize polarized light,
which often require measurements at different times. This limits high-resolution polarized light imaging; a process
that is critical for applications ranging from astronomy to biomedical imaging to pharmaceuticals. The research
under this grant will investigate the development of a polarized light detector (polarimeter) capable of overcoming
existing limitations, as well as adding new functionality not currently available. This will be achieved by taking
advantage of the unique optoelectronic properties of polymer semiconductors. Multiple semitransparent organic
photodetectors will be processed at a single spatial location and the multicell stack will be optimized to develop
a polarimeter with advanced capabilities. This grant also provides an opportunity to develop outreach activities
to interest high school students, both locally and nationally, in optical science and engineering.

Technical Abstract: The objective of this proposal is to investigate the use of organic photovoltaic modules as
inherently polarization sensitive detectors. Current methods of polarization imaging or detection rely on either
time-sequential or instantaneous measurements taken after light transmits through polarization sensitive elements.
These, often complex, optical systems are necessary because there are no current detector technologies capable of
measuring the complete polarization state, at a single spatial location, within a single integration time.
This results in several disadvantages associated with existing technologies; chief among them are temporal and/or
spatial misregistration that causes errors in the sensed polarization elements. To alleviate these errors, this
proposal details a novel strain-aligned polymer-based photodetector that is inherently polarization sensitive.
The objectives are to: (1) Create an optoelectronic model of multi-layer organic photovoltaics (OPVs);
(2) Create a free-space polarimeter design, using multiple semi-transparent SOPD proof of concept devices;
(3) Design and create an experimental proof of principle multi-layer monolithic polarimeter based on S-OPDs;
(4) Leverage the model and concept to create calibration procedures; and (5) Explore multi-spectral and
multi-Stokes detectors, including their incorporation into arrays and unique geometrical structures.

Polymer semiconductors commonly have a primary optical dipole transition that is
parallel to the conjugated backbone. Thus, uniaxially aligning the polymer in one-direction results in
anisotropic optical detection. The intellectual merit of this proposal is through the study of the device
performance opportunities enabled by aligned polymer based polarimeters with inherent polarization
sensitivity. Merit is found in: (1) The optimization of OPV structures, biasing, and circuitry for use in
photodetection processes; (2) Developing insight into how alignment and anisotropy influence
energy conversion; (3) Establishing advanced optoelectronic modeling of complex multi-layer
anisotropic organic photodetectors at various angles of incidence; and (4) Calibration procedures,
algorithms, and techniques for using OPVs as polarization-sensitive photovoltaic detectors. The
proposed endeavor has the potential to create broad new areas of research in multi-dimensional
monolithic optical sensing.

The proposed research has significant commercial potential, benefiting the fields
of telecommunications, remote sensing, and biomedical imaging. This project will also provide
support for two graduate student researchers in polarimetry and device fabrication. Dissemination of
research results will occur through publications and outreach efforts to the general public will also be
conducted by both PIs. For instance, online tutorials to garner excitement for polarimetric imaging
will be produced that include fabrication tutorials and software development that would place
polarimetric imaging at the hands of amateur hobbyists and students. Additionally, the PIs will
contribute to a week-long high school summer camp held at NC State to attract students to
engineering careers. In this camp, outreach modules related to polarized light in nature will be
created and disseminated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate a new kind of polarization sensitive detector system and apply it towards polarimetric detection. The new polarimeter architecture, referred to as an intrinsic coincident polarimeter, is able to measure the light’s polarization within a single spatial location at a single instant in time. This offers advantages over competing architectures in that it enables full use of the light (most conventional systems reject half the light) while maintaining a compact and monolithic form factor. In the future, these new detector architectures will enable advanced forms of multidimensional sensing, including combined polarimetric, spectral and distance sensing that can be applied to consumer applications, including automated cars, chemical sensing, and mobile phones. Four graduate students were supported by this grant. Outreach was also conducted during this grant through leading K-12 science camp activities.

 

The specific activities and outcomes were as follows:

1. Create accurate optoelectronic models describing strain-aligned organic photodetector (S-OPD) polarimetry. The goal of this objective was to calculate the detector's optical, polarization, electrical, and noise properties for up to four cascaded organic photovoltaic cells. This also included optimizing the stacked detector architectures. Key outcomes and achievements: We (1) Established a model for S-OPD absorption and transmission; (2) Introduced responsivity terms into the model to account for differential response between parallel and perpendicularly polarized light, relative to the strain direction; and (3) Established a relationship between the polarization diattenuation and strain for optimization purposes.

 

2. Explore capabilities and design individual S-OPD detectors for Stokes polarimetry. Individual devices were fabricated and incorporated into a free-space 4-detector polarimeter to optimize fabrication procedures and validate the model. Key outcomes and achievements: We (1) Created and characterized strain-aligned OPD devices experimentally; (2) Quantified environmental degradation; (3) Studied strain limits as related to key parameters for polarimetry (e.g., diattenuation, retardance, etc.). (4) Created an opto-electronic model of a free-space linear and full Stokes polarimeter; (5) Created optimization algorithms and procedures and compared the intrinsic polarimeter to current state of the art polarimeters; (6) Performed an error analysis framed in the context of the polarimeter’s matrix condition number and Frobenius norm; and (7) Incorporated additional degrees of freedom into the model to enable improved measurement of circular and elliptical polarization states.

 

3. Design monolithic tandem S-OPD cell and fabricate proof of concept device. In this objective, we used the validated model to design monolithically stacked detector elements. We also produced a basic proof of concept for the first monolithic multilayer polarimeter. Key outcomes and achievements: We (1) Fabricated monolithic tandem cells by joining independent S-OPD detectors together; and (2) Created new types of electrodes to improve transparency for monolithic devices;

 

4. Calibration, validation, and performance assessment of monolithic S-OPD. Experimentation and modeling were performed to establish the S-OPD's calibration parameters and to explore the device's full capabilities. Key outcomes and achievements: We (1) Created an optical and electrical model that allowed the cross-talk between different detectors to be quantified; and (2) Modeled and quantified the angle of incidence response for both 2-cell and 4-cell monolithic devices.

 

5. Investigate multi-spectral sensing and expand detector geometries. Concepts were explored, using combinatorial organic materials, for multispectral sensing. Key outcomes and achievements: We (1) Investigated new materials systems for improved multi-spectral sensing, with enhanced detectivity in the near infrared (700-1000 nm); and (2) Investigated strain alignment relationships and performance (detectivity, quantum efficiency, speed) for an all polymer active layer of pBnDT-FTAZ:P(NDI2OD-T2), and PTB7-Th and DPP-4T polymers blended with small molecules (IT-M, PC71BM).

 

6. Investigate imaging capability of monolithic S-OPD. Use the intrinsic polarimeter architecture to measure two-dimensional spatial Stokes parameter distribution of a scene. Imaging configuration and performance will be investigated. Key outcomes and achievements: We (1) Demonstrated use of single S-OPD detector in conjunction with a digital light projection (DLP) mirror assembly for compressed imaging; and (2) Applied a rotating polarimeter calibration to DLP-based compressive sensing hardware to enable measurement of full Stokes vectors. 

7. Participated in K-12 science day camps. Lead camp activities that introduce optics and polarized light to 8th graders as part of week-long summer day camps held as NC State.
